Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Using Data Science and Biophysical Models to Address the COVID-19 Pandemic
Award.AbstractNarration: COVID-19, the disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, is at the center of one of the most dangerous pandemics the world has ever known. As it spreads through the human population the virus mutates producing proteins that can lead to higher infection rates (infectivity), and an increased ability to cause severe disease (virulence). This project will predict the most likely mutations of the virus by combining methods from machine learning, mathematics and biophysics. Specifically, the proteins resulting from viral mutations will be experimentally synthesized, and their infectivity and virulence will be tested by the project team through a collaboration with researchers in industry. This project benefits from unprecedented access to genomic data compiled on SARS-CoV-2, combined with a rich set of novel tools developed through interdisciplinary advances in data science, mathematics, and biophysics. The results of this project will build a pipeline capable of assisting the development of vaccines and drugs against COVID-19 while simultaneously advancing the fields of machine learning and mathematical virology. The project team is led by mathematicians, molecular biologists and biotechnology experts working in an interdisciplinary and collaborative setting. Students and postdoctoral researchers will be trained and will participate in publicly disseminating the findings and results of the project.<br/><br/> <br/>The SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus is believed to have originated as a bat virus and to have evolved through a combination of sequence mutations, recombination, and natural selection to be infectious in human hosts. Some of the most relevant sequence variations occurred in the S gene encoding the Spike (S) protein. As SARS-CoV-2 spreads through the human population, mutations of the S gene can potentially increase viral infectivity and virulence. Within the framework of an evolutionary algorithm, the PIs will combine graph theory, topological data analysis, and computational biophysics to characterize the most likely mutations of the S protein. This powerful interdisciplinary approach will draw upon existing experimental data from SARS-CoV-2. The PIs will collaborate with an industrial partner to experimentally design the peptides corresponding to those predicted sequences, and use binding affinity assays and cryo-electron microscopy to test binding of the peptides to the human receptor (ACE2). The resulting pipeline will help us better understand the evolutionary landscape of viral proteins and will assist researchers in the development of anti-viral drugs and vaccines. Future extensions of this work will increase our understanding of how viruses are transmitted across species and propagate in humans. The project will provide multi-disciplinary student and postdoctoral training. The PIs will broadly disseminate their results, as well as the data they collect and software they design.<br/><br/>With this award, the Mathematical Biology Program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry are supporting Drs. Arsuaga, Rodriguez, and Vazquez from University of California-Davis to study genomic variations of the SARS-CoV-2 viral spike (S) protein and predict the expansion range of transmission in human populations.<br/><br/>This grant is being awarded using funds made available by the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act supplemental funds allocated to MPS.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID-19 pandemic, a public health crisis that spanned several years and touched on every aspect of our society, was caused by the coronavirus SARS-CoV2. Infection by this virus starts when its spike (S) protein binds to a host cell. Mutations in the S protein appeared as the virus spread through the human population, sometimes leading to higher infection rates and an increased ability to cause severe disease. This RAPID award supported the development of methods to predict the most likely mutations of SARS-CoV2. Specifically, we combined methods from mathematics, machine learning and biophysics to predict mutations in the S protein that would be more likely to increase infectivity of a human host.  We started collaborations with other scientists to experimentally synthesize viral proteins of interest and test their binding affinity to human receptors. As a result of this project we built an interdisciplinary pipeline to predict mutations in coronaviruses that can cause higher infectivity. 

An important challenge in vital evolution is to identify non-human animal coronaviruses that may infect humans. To tackle this problem we created an artificial neural network model that learns from the binding of the S protein of alpha and beta coronaviruses to their host receptor. This model produces a human-Binding Potential (h-BiP) score that can distinguish the binding potential among human coronaviruses with high accuracy. We used this model to identify two previously unknown viruses, Bat coronavirus BtCoV/133/2005 and Rhinolophus affinis coronavirus isolate LYRa3, which have the potential to bind human receptors. Importantly the model predicted that the S protein of SARS-CoV2 woudl bind a human receptor. This approach shows that machine learning methods can be used to predict host expansion events and can be used for surveillance of novel coronaviruses. [https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.12.11.520008v1.abstract]

In a separate subproject and in collaboration with a group of biophysicists at UC Davis, we used AlphaFold to predict the structures of the furin enzyme with known six residue inhibitory peptides. This approach was used to study the wild type furin cleavage domain for the virus and several mutants. We found that the delta variant has a high binding strength with the furin enzyme. This information can be used to inform the development of drugs that target the furin enzyme and prevent the spread of the virus. [https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.01.04.475011v1.abstract]

Our work has significant implications for advancing our understanding of the evolutionary landscape of viral proteins, viral transmission, and propagation in humans. Our interdisciplinary approach, combining data science, mathematics, and biophysics, has the potential to aid in drug development.

Throughout the project, we have been committed to training students researchers in interdisciplinary research and disseminating their findings to the public. We contributed to the education of young researchers by training 15 undergraduates, two graduate students, and three high school students, providing them with hands-on research experience. We helped organize an NSF-sponsored undergraduate research conference on the mathematical modeling of COVID-19. This conference provided a platform for young researchers to present their work and exchange ideas with experts in the field. Members of our team presented their research to a variety of audiences and in various formats, including conferences, webinars, and seminars. Results of the research are reported in two research papers (submitted for publication), one undergraduate thesis and one PhD thesis. 

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2023
Modified by: Javier Arsuaga

Infection by this virus starts when its spike (S) protein binds to a host cell. Mutations in the S protein appeared as the virus spread through the human population, sometimes leading to higher infection rates and an increased ability to cause severe disease. This RAPID award supported the development of methods to predict the most likely mutations of SARS-CoV2. Specifically, we combined methods from mathematics, machine learning and biophysics to predict mutations in the S protein that would be more likely to increase infectivity of a human host. We started collaborations with other scientists to experimentally synthesize viral proteins of interest and test their binding affinity to human receptors. As a result of this project we built an interdisciplinary pipeline to predict mutations in coronaviruses that can cause higher infectivity. An important challenge in vital evolution is to identify non-human animal coronaviruses that may infect humans.
